Graphical abstract Tuning the nanoparticle-support interaction can optimize the catalytic performance of supported metal oxide catalysts for VOCs removal. Herein, a series of Co3O4/CeO2 catalysts with different strengths of interfacial interaction and electron transfer were successfully constructed via various modified wetness impregnation procedures. With the introduction of ammonium hydroxide, citric acid or H2 pretreatment, a stronger interfacial interaction and electron transfer were achieved due to the highly Co3O4 dispersion and CeO2 surface reconstruction. The modified-synthesis Co3O4/CeO2 catalysts, particularly Co3O4/CeO2-CA (citric acid), demonstrated superior catalytic activity (T90 = 296 °C, TOF = 0.337 × 10−3 s−1) and stability for propane oxidation as compared to typical wetness impregnation Co3O4/CeO2-DI (T90 = 314 °C, TOF = 0.121 × 10−3 s−1). Through systematic characterizations and DFT calculation, the strong interfacial interaction and abundant reactive oxygen species facilitate the adsorption and activation of C3H8 and O2 on the catalyst surface, which further promote the intermediates (carbonate/carboxyl species) transformation. These findings highlight interfacial mechanism to catalytic performance optimization of supported metal oxides. Keywords VOCs removal Supported Co3O4 catalyst Interfacial interaction Reaction mechanism Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are regarded as significant precursors to the formation of ozone pollution and photochemical smog, presenting substantial risks to both the environment and human health. The primary sources of VOCs is the petrochemical, coating, chemical engineering and printing industries [1]. Specifically, propane, emitted from the liquefied petroleum gas fueled chemical industries, accounting for a large proportion of VOCs emissions, has become a prominent air pollutant and a widely studied model VOC [2]. Given the stable C–H bond in short-chain alkanes, catalytic oxidation at low temperature is considered a dependable approach for efficiently eliminating propane, which has been successfully applied in industrial exhaust treatment [3,4]. The crucial of catalytic oxidation technology is the design and development of catalysts with outstanding activity, long-term stability and cost-effectiveness. Up to now, noble metal catalysts, such as Pt, Pd, Ru, Au, etc have exhibited exceptional catalytic activity in VOCs oxidation, but high cost and finite availability impeded their widespread application [5]. Therefore, the exploration of high performance and durable non-precious catalysts for VOCs catalytic oxidation is currently a popular research topic. Transition metal oxides, represented by Co3O4, possess the advantages of multiple Co valence, unoccupied d orbitals, strong redox properties, abundant active oxygen and rich resources, emerged to be potential alternatives for noble metal catalysts [4,6]. Many efforts have been dedicated to precisely tuning the properties of Co3O4, such as elemental doping [7], crystal plane exposure [8], and defect engineering [9], with the aim of improving its catalytic activity. Generally, these isolated Co3O4 nanoparticles are prone to agglomerate at elevated temperatures, resulting in deactivation of the catalytic performance as the particle size increases [10]. Depositing the Co3O4 nanoparticles onto specific types of supports, such as SiO2, Al2O3, TiO2 and CeO2, proves to be an effective approach for acquiring well-dispersed Co3O4 catalysts [11]. The supports hold significant importance, not only for their function in dispersing surface cobalt oxides, but also due to the presence of interfacial interactions between cobalt oxide and support, which would greatly influence the stabilization and content of active cobalt oxides [12]. CeO2, known as a rare earth oxide, has been widely used as a support in the catalytic reaction owing to its distinctive oxygen storage/release capacity, redox properties, and abundant oxygen vacancies resulting from the intrinsic Ce3+/Ce4+ redox pair [7,13,14]. Researches have demonstrated that the supported catalysts consisting of metal/metal oxide and CeO2 support exhibit superior catalytic activity in the case of Ru/CeO2, Pt/CeO2, and MoOx/CeO2 [14–16]. Besides, the Co3O4/CeO2 catalyst has also been reported to exhibit excellent activity in soot removal, methane combustion and CO oxidation [17–19]. The methodology employed to fabricate supported catalysts is widely recognized for its pivotal role in controlling the dispersion, specific surface area, interaction strength, and other textural and structural properties of metal-oxide catalysts, which in turn influence the catalytic performance [20]. For instance, Liu et al. employed a H2 pre-reduction and post-oxidation strategy to successfully modulate the surface Co3+ species and lattice O2− content in Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst, leading to a substantial enhancement in propane oxidation activity [21]. Wang et al. used a two-stage process involving incipient wetness impregnation and combustion synthesis to prepare Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, and found that the method afforded Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 catalyst with high Co3O4 dispersion and abundant surface Co3+ [20]. Furthermore, Fischer et al. reported four distinct supporting methods to modify the interactions between nanoparticle and the supporting materials (nanoparticle-support interaction or NPSI). These methods entail contacting the Al2O3 support with various cobalt substances (e,g., Co(NO3)2, Co(OH)x or Co3O4) at diverse phases of the reverse micelle technique or catalyst pretreatment [22]. Building upon these findings, modifications in the interaction between CeO2 and diverse Co species during the synthesis or pretreatment of Co3O4/CeO2 catalysts could potentially influence the dispersion, interaction strength, and catalytic performance of Co3O4/CeO2 catalyst. However, limited investigation has been conducted on this particular topic. Therefore, the uniqueness of our work lies in the manipulation of Co3O4 nanoparticle dispersion and the interaction with CeO2 support to affect the activity and phase stability of Co3O4/CeO2 during propane oxidation. Based on the hypothesis that the contact between the CeO2 support and various Co species during the synthesis process affects the catalytic performance of the Co3O4/CeO2 catalyst, a series of Co3O4/CeO2 catalysts were synthesized using wetness impregnation method with the introduction of ammonium hydroxide, citric acid and H2 pretreatment, respectively, during the synthesis process. We endeavored to comprehend the chemical and structural characteristics of the Co3O4/CeO2 catalyst synthesized by different modification procedures, and to establish a relationship between catalyst properties and the activity for propane oxidation. Further kinetic studies and in situ DRIFTS were employed to offer insights into the reaction mechanism of propane oxidation. Additionally, the influence of water vapor on catalytic activity and stability over the Co3O4/CeO2 would also be investigated. This work will elucidate a feasible strategy for exploiting advanced supported Co3O4 catalysts to accelerate the propane total oxidation. 2 Experimental section Analytical-grade purity was maintained for all chemicals and reagents obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. The gases procured from Dalian Special Gases Co., Ltd, including C3H8 (>99.99 %), O2 (>99.999 %), Ar (>99.999 %), 2 vol% O2/He, 10 vol% H2/Ar, and other gases, were utilized for reaction and characterization. No additional purification was required for the reagents and gases implemented in this study. 2.1 Synthesis of materials The CeO2 support was synthesized by sol–gel method, similar to the procedure outlined in [7,9]. Briefly, Ce(NO3)3⋅6H2O was dissolved in deionized water (60 mL), followed by an excess of citric acid solution added and stirred at 60 °C for 1 h. Then, the above mixed solution was rotary-evaporated to a gelatinous substance, dried at 100 °C for 12 h, and calcinated at 500 °C under air flow for 4 h. The Co3O4/CeO2 sample containing 15 wt% Co3O4 loading was prepared via the wetness impregnation method. Accordingly, CeO2 support (1 g) was dispersed in deionized water (30 mL) with Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (2.2 mmol). Then, 10 mL of deionized water, or 10 mL of ammonium hydroxide solution (AM, 4.84 mmol), or 10 mL of citric acid solution (CA, 2.64 mmol), was dropped into the above suspension under continuous stirring. After 6 h of stirring and impregnation, the suspension was transferred to a rotary evaporator to remove excess water at 60 °C. In the case of ammonia solution suspension, the rotary evaporation step was substituted with a filtration and washing procedure. Ultimately, the precipitate was dried at 80 °C for 12 h, followed by calcination at 400 °C under air flow for 3 h. The corresponding samples are designated Co3O4/CeO2, Co3O4/CeO2-AM and Co3O4/CeO2-CA, respectively. The Co3O4/CeO2-HR sample was prepared using the method similar to the above method of Co3O4/CeO2 except for the calcination condition, of which the sample was pre-reduced under H2 flow at 150 °C for 1 h, then calcined under air flow for 3 h at 400 °C. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The composition, structure, and physicochemical properties of all Co3O4/CeO2 samples were analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns, N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms, transmission electron microscope (TEM) images, energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), Raman analysis, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), pulse O2 chemisorption, and oxygen temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD). C3H8 catalytic oxidation mechanism of the catalysts were characterized by C3H8-TPD, C3H8-TPSR and in situ DRIFTS. The additional details are provided in Supplementary Material. 2.3 Computational models and methods All the spin-polarized calculations were performed by density functional theory as implemented in the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [23,24]. Considering the exchange–correlation functional, the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof function (PBE) [25] was selected. A Hubbard U term was added to the PBE functional (PBE + U) employing the rotationally invariant formalism by Dudrev et al. [26], where only the difference (Ueff = U-J) between the Coulomb U and exchange J parameters enters. The Ueff values of Co and Ce were set to 3.5 and 4.5 eV, respectively, according to the previous studies [27,28]. Additionally, the Grimme’s DFT-D3 [29] was added to examine the effect of van der Waals interaction on reaction energy. The cutoff energy was set as 400 eV. The ions relaxation was achieved until the force for per atom is less than 0.02 eV/Å and the total energy converged to 10−5 eV. A vacuum height of 15 Å was used to eliminate the interaction between neighboring slabs. For the model construction, the optimized crystal lattice parameter of Co3O4 (Fd3̅m, 227) is a = 8.05 Å, b = 8.05 Å, c = 8.05 Å, α = 90.00°, β = 90.00°, ɣ=90.00°, which is from the website https://www.materialsproject.org/. Four-layer p(2 × 2) surface slab (two layers at bottom were frozen and the others were completely relaxed) was built for the Co3O4 (110) surface. The size of the p(2 × 2) slab model is about 14.5 × 11.5 × 4.4 Å for Co3O4 (110). The slab models of Co3O4-CeO2 interface were constructed by loading or doping Ce atoms on the Co3O4 surface. A 3 × 3 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack grid k-point was set in the surface Brillouin zone. The formation energy of an oxygen vacancy (EOv) was calculated by: (1) E O v = E ( s l a b , O v ) - E s l a b + 1 2 E O 2 where E (slab, Ov) is the energy of the defective Co3O4 slab surface, E slab is the energy of the bare slab surface, and E O2 is the energy of gaseous oxygen molecule. The change of free energy for the adsorption E (slab, adsorbate) of target by the catalyst substrate is defined by: (2) E ( a d s , a d s o r b a t e ) = E ( s l a b , a d s o r b a t e ) - E s l a b - E a d s o r b a t e where E (slab, adsorbate) is the total energy of an adsorbate bound to the Co3O4 (110) slab, E adsorbate is the total energy of an isolated molecule or intermediate, E slab is the total energy of the bare slab. 2.4 Catalytic performance evaluation Catalyst activity assessments for propane catalytic oxidation utilizing a fixed-bed reactor were conducted under atmospheric pressure. The catalysts, comprising 200 mg, were appropriately diluted with quartz (2 mL, 60–80 mesh) to mitigate the occurrence of hotspots. The reactant gas encompassed 0.2 vol% C3H8, 5 vol% O2, and balanced Ar, with the total flow rate of 200 mL min−1, giving a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 60000 mL g−1h−1. For the stability assessment, 2.5 vol% water vapor was introduced into the reactant gas. The outlet gas was monitored by a chromatograph (GC7900) equipped with both FID and TCD detectors. Formulas governing the determination of propane conversion (X% ) and specific reaction rate (rs ) are as follows: (3) X % = C in - C out C in × 100 % (4) r s = F X % m cat S BET where Cin and Cout represent the concentrations of propane at the inlet and outlet gas, respectively. F represents the propane flow rate (mol s−1), SBET represents the specific surface area (m2 g−1), and mcat stands for the catalyst mass (g). Turnover frequency (TOF) is defined by the following formula: (5) TOF = F X % 2 m cat V O 2 where F, X% , mcat and V O 2 represent the propane flow rate (mol s−1), propane conversion (%), catalyst mass (g) and active sites amount (μmol/g). The number of V O 2 is calculated based on the utilization of pulse O2 chemisorption. Furthermore, the calculation of TOF is confined to propane conversion below 20 %, so as to exclude heat or mass transfer limitation. Additionally, the assessment of mass diffusion transport limitations is conducted employing the Weisz-Prater criterion [30]: (6) N W - P = - r A ρ c R 2 C As D e < 1 Comprehensive calculations for the Weisz-Prater criterion are presented in the Supplementary Information. The calculated N W-P value in this case is 0.77 × 10−3, indicating the ignorance of mass transfer limitation in the activity assessment. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural properties of Co3O4/CeO2 samples The XRD patterns of the synthesized Co3O4/CeO2 samples are shown in Fig. 1 a. For Co3O4/CeO2-DI sample, the diffraction peaks at 28.6°, 33.1°, 56.3°, and 76.7° were assigned to the (111), (200), (220), (311) and (331) planes of CeO2 (PDF#034-0394), respectively, while the diffraction peaks at 19.1°, 31.3°, 36.9°, 59.4° and 65.3° were indexed to (111), (220), (311), (511) and (440) planes of Co3O4 (PDF#043-1003), respectively. It can be observed that the characteristic diffraction peaks of cubic fluorite CeO2 structure and spinel Co3O4 structure were detected for all Co3O4/CeO2 samples. According to Scherrer equation, the crystallite size of Co3O4 in Co3O4/CeO2-CA (15.6 nm) and Co3O4/CeO2-AM (17.8 nm) was slightly smaller compared to that of Co3O4/CeO2-DI (26.9 nm) sample. This reveals that the addition of CA and AM in synthesis procedure is conducive to the formation of smaller crystallites, which may be due to the Co ion likely forming Co(CA)x or Co(OH)x with citrate root or OH−, thus preventing the aggregation of the nanoparticle during the calcination process [22,31]. In addition, the crystallite size of Co3O4/CeO2-HR (27.0 nm) was similar to that of Co3O4/CeO2-DI, indicating that the pre-reduction process has little effect on the crystallite size of Co3O4. The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of the Co3O4/CeO2 samples are presented in Fig. 1b and S1. All supported Co3O4/CeO2 samples exhibited typical Ⅳ isotherms with a H3-type hysteresis loop, suggesting the presence of mesopores within the catalysts. The corresponding values for specific surface area, average pore size and total pore volume are detailed in Table 1 and Fig. S2. Specifically, the specific surface area of CeO2 is 60 m2 g−1, while that of Co3O4/CeO2-DI, Co3O4/CeO2-HR, Co3O4/CeO2-CA, Co3O4/CeO2-AM samples is 48, 42, 50, and 54 m2 g−1, respectively. This indicates that Co3O4 loading on CeO2 surface led to a reduction of the specific surface area. Additionally, Co3O4/CeO2-HR displayed the smallest specific surface area and pore volume (0.098 cm3 g−1), which is mostly likely due to the reconstruction of CeO2 surface during the pre-reduction process [32]. Contrarily, both the specific surface area of Co3O4/CeO2-CA and Co3O4/CeO2-AM are higher compared to that of Co3O4/CeO2-DI. The increased specific surface area of the supported Co3O4/CeO2 refers to a higher dispersion of Co3O4. This observation reveals that the introduction of CA and AM facilitates the dispersion of Co3O4, contributing positively to the catalytic performance. To gain further insight into the structural characteristics of the Co3O4/CeO2 samples, Raman tests was carried out and shown in Fig. 2 . For all Co3O4/CeO2 samples, Raman peaks located at 191, 515, 612 and 683 cm−1 were assigned to the 3F2g and A1g modes of Co3O4, respectively, and the prominent peak at 460 cm−1 corresponded to the F2g mode of CeO2 in cubic fluorite structure [14,33]. When compared to Co3O4/CeO2-DI, the primary A1g mode of Co3O4/CeO2-AM and Co3O4/CeO2-CA exhibited a shift towards higher wavelengths, accompanying by significant peak broadening. These observations indicate a reduction in the symmetry of the Co3O4 lattice, potentially resulting in surface lattice disorder and the generation of oxygen vacancy defects [34,35]. Meanwhile, the downshift of A1g peak in Co3O4/CeO2-HR to a lower wavenumber can be attributed to the elongation of Co-O band and a decrease in binding strength. The peak intensities of F2g and A1g can provide insight into the extent of Co3O4 dispersion on the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 2c, the IF2g/IAg ratio of Co3O4/CeO2-DI, Co3O4/CeO2-HR, Co3O4/CeO2-CA, and Co3O4/CeO2-AM samples were 0.77, 0.60, 5.7, and 4.4, respectively. Combing with XRD and BET analyses, it suggested a well-dispersed nature of Co3O4 species on the surfaces of Co3O4/CeO2-CA and Co3O4/CeO2-AM samples, which likely contributes to a strong interaction between Co3O4 and CeO2, thereby providing active centers for the catalytic oxidation of propane. In addition to the Raman spectra acquired at visible band, data obtained at the ultraviolet band can also analyze the information of oxygen vacancies in the materials. As depicted in Fig. 2b, the Co3O4/CeO2 samples exhibit the characteristic F2g and defect-induced D vibrations of CeO2 at 465 cm−1 and 590 cm−1, respectively, together with the 2LO vibration center at 1176 cm−1 [36]. Generally, the intensity ratio between the peak D and the peak F2g reflects the surface oxygen vacancy concentration of the catalyst [37]. The calculated value of ID/IF2g for the Co3O4/CeO2 samples are presented in Fig. 2c: 0.44, 0.48, 0.48 and 0.41 for Co3O4/CeO2-DI, Co3O4/CeO2-HR, Co3O4/CeO2-CA, and Co3O4/CeO2-AM, respectively. These results indicate that Co3O4/CeO2-CA and Co3O4/CeO2-HR samples possess a higher oxygen vacancy concentration on their surfaces. This could be attributed to the vibration of highly dispersed Co3O4 interacting with the CeO2 support or the reconstruction of the CeO2 surface after H2 pretreatment, resulting in the formation of Co-O-Ce bonds and subsequent generation of oxygen vacancies in the cerium oxide lattice. The morphology of the synthesized Co3O4/CeO2 samples was observed by TEM. As shown in Fig. 3 a-d, the synthesized Co3O4/CeO2 samples exhibited uniformly small particles with average size of 15–25 nm, and no significant change in catalyst size occurred with the different synthesis procedures. Fig. 3e-h shows the HRTEM images of the Co3O4/CeO2 samples. The lattice fringes with spacing of 0.24 and 0.28 nm corresponded to the (311) and (220) crystal planes of Co3O4, respectively, while the lattice spacing of 0.27 and 0.31 nm were assigned to the (200) and (111) crystal planes of CeO2. No variation in the detected crystal planes was observed among the four Co3O4/CeO2 samples. TEM-EDS mapping (Fig. 3i) was employed to investigate the spatial distributions of Ce, Co and O elements, confirming their uniform dispersion. Additionally, the TEM-EDS mapping results provide evidence of the effective dispersion of Co3O4 species on the CeO2 support. 3.2 Surface chemical properties The redox properties of the synthesized Co3O4/CeO2 samples were investigated by H2-TPR. CeO2 support exhibited two reduction peaks at 485 and 775 °C (shown in Fig. S3), ascribed to the reduction of surface lattice oxygen species and bulk lattice oxygen species of CeO2, respectively. For Co3O4/CeO2 samples (Fig. 4 a), three reduction peaks were presented on the curves of each sample, corresponding to a three-step reduction process. The first two reduction peaks located around 270 and 330 °C corresponded to the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ and Co2+ to Co, respectively, while the last reduction peak at ca. 430 °C was attributed to the reduction of surface lattice oxygen in CeO2. It is evident that the first two reduction peak temperatures of Co3O4/CeO2-HR (276 °C, 332 °C), Co3O4/CeO2-CA (258 °C, 321 °C), and Co3O4/CeO2-AM (274 °C, 321 °C) are lower than those of Co3O4/CeO2-DI (278 °C, 337 °C), indicating the better low-temperature reducibility in Co3O4/CeO2-HR, Co3O4/CeO2-CA and Co3O4/CeO2-AM samples. Besides, the reduction peak associated with CeO2 surface lattice oxygen in Co3O4/CeO2 samples shifted to lower temperatures compared to the CeO2 support, and the reduction peak of Co3O4/CeO2-HR, Co3O4/CeO2-CA and Co3O4/CeO2-AM samples were more pronounced than that of Co3O4/CeO2-DI. This observation demonstrates the influence of Co3O4 introduction to CeO2 on the mobility of surface lattice oxygen. As reported, CeO2 possesses a strong ability to amplify mobility of oxygen species in catalysts, owing to the possible coupling between Co2+/Co3+ and Ce3+/Ce4+ redox pairs. This explains the enhanced reducibility of the modified synthesis Co3O4/CeO2 samples due to the strong synergistic interaction between Co3O4 and CeO2. The relatively lower reduction temperature and strong peak intensity indicate the better reducibility of Co3O4/CeO2-HR, Co3O4/CeO2-CA and Co3O4/CeO2-AM samples that is expected to be advantageous for enhancing catalytic performance. The oxidation properties of the synthesized Co3O4/CeO2 samples were evaluated by O2-TPD, as shown in Fig. 4b. All samples exhibited three distinct desorption peaks at the temperature range of 50 to 650 °C, which are attributed to physically adsorbed oxygen or O2 − species (α, below 120 °C), surface chemisorbed oxygen species (β, ∼150 °C), and surface lattice oxygen (γ, 300–450 °C), respectively [38]. For the desorption peaks of physiosorbed and chemisorbed oxygen species, no shifts of desorption temperature were observed, apart from the desorption amount of chemisorbed oxygen species, wherein Co3O4/CeO2-CA and Co3O4/CeO2-AM samples exhibited a more obvious peak β. This indicates that the Co3O4/CeO2-CA and Co3O4/CeO2-AM samples have a strong capacity for oxygen release. Notably, the desorption peak of surface lattice oxygen (peak γ) in the modified-synthesis Co3O4/CeO2 samples shifted to lower temperature compared to Co3O4/CeO2-DI, indicating faster mobility of surface oxygen species in modified-synthesis Co3O4/CeO2. Furthermore, the O2 uptake curves (shown in Fig. 4c) also indicated a greater uptake of oxygen on the surface of the modified-synthesis Co3O4/CeO2 samples at 220 °C, implying the presence of more active oxygen species. Collectively, these results indicate that the modified-synthesis Co3O4/CeO2 samples, especially Co3O4/CeO2-CA, possess a substantial quantity of surface reactive oxygen species, which directly contributes to superior catalytic performance for propane oxidation. The surface elements and valence state of the samples were probed using XPS technique, as illustrated in Fig. 5 . In the Co 2p XPS spectra (Fig. 5a), two characteristic peaks at ∼ 780 and ∼ 795 eV are attributed to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2, respectively, which were further deconvolved into Co3+ (∼779.4 eV and ∼ 794.5 eV) and Co2+ (∼780.8 eV and ∼ 795.9 eV). According to the fitting result, the surface Co3+/Co2+ molar ratios were calculated and listed in Table 1, following the sequence of Co3O4/CeO2-CA (0.81) > Co3O4/CeO2-AM (0.76) > Co3O4/CeO2-HR (0.73) > Co3O4/CeO2-DI (0.69). The highest value of Co3+/Co2+ on Co3O4/CeO2-CA implies the substantial presence of Co3+ species on Co3O4/CeO2-CA surface. As previously reported, a higher proportion of surface Co3+ species, serving as the active sites, can enhance the activation and migration of oxygen species [39]. Consequently, the modified-synthesis Co3O4/CeO2 samples, especially Co3O4/CeO2-CA, are likely to exhibit enhanced catalytic performance in propane oxidation. Considering the CeO2 support, the increased Co3+ content of the modified-synthesis Co3O4/CeO2 samples may stem from an interfacial electron transfer between Co3O4 and CeO2 (Co2+ + CeO2 → Co3++ 1/2 Ce2O3 + Ov), which results in the creation of Ce3+ and oxygen vacancies [40]. Regarding the Ce 3d spectra (Fig. 5b), the curves were deconvolved into ten peaks, for which the six peaks labeled as v, v″, v‴, u, u′′ and u‴ were assigned to Ce4+, while the remaining four peaks namely v0, v′, u0, and u′ were attributed to Ce3+ [41]. Similarly, the elevated Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio on the modified-synthesis Co3O4/CeO2 samples (Co3O4/CeO2-CA, 0.37) provides the further evidence for the interfacial electron transfer between Co3O4 and CeO2 through the redox cycle (Co2+/Co3+ and Ce3+/Ce4+). Fig. 5c presents the O 1 s spectra of the synthesized Co3O4/CeO2 samples, which were deconvoluted into three peaks at ∼ 529.2, ∼530.8, and ∼ 532.0 eV, corresponding to lattice oxygen (Olatt, O2−), defect oxide or surface adsorbed oxygen (Oads, e.g. O2 − or O−), and hydroxyl groups (OH), respectively [38]. The Oads/Olatt ratio was calculated and summarized in Table 2 . The Oads/Olatt ratios of modified-synthesis Co3O4/CeO2 samples exhibit an obvious increase when compared to Co3O4/CeO2-DI, indicative of more active oxygen species. Specifically, the Oads/Olatt ratios for Co3O4/CeO2-AM (0.24), Co3O4/CeO2-CA (0.20) and Co3O4/CeO2-HR (0.19) are higher than that of Co3O4/CeO2-DI (0.16). Evidently, the presence of more active oxygen species facilitates the C3H8 oxidation through the Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism. Besides, the O 1 s peak shift is related to the charge of oxide ions and is affected by the surrounding chemical environment. Thus, the obvious O 1 s peak shift over the modified-synthesis Co3O4/CeO2 samples confirmed the heightened interfacial interaction between Co3O4 and CeO2. 3.3 Catalytic performance Fig. 6 shows the catalytic activity of the synthesized Co3O4/CeO2 catalysts for propane oxidation, with the corresponding T50 and T90 presented in Table 2. The modified-synthesis approach significantly improved the catalytic activity of the Co3O4/CeO2 catalysts for propane oxidation. Among all Co3O4/CeO2 catalysts, Co3O4/CeO2-CA exhibited the highest catalytic activity, with the T50 and T90 reduced to 263 and 296 °C, respectively, as compared to those of Co3O4/CeO2-DI (T50 = 285 °C, T90 = 314 °C). To study the intrinsic catalytic activity while eliminating the effect of specific surface area on catalytic performance, the specific reaction rate normalized by the SBET value was calculated and is shown in Table 2. The specific reaction rate was decrease in the same order of the catalytic performance: Co3O4/CeO2-CA (3.27 × 10−9 mol m−2 s−1) > Co3O4/CeO2-HR (2.34 × 10−9 mol m−2 s−1) > Co3O4/CeO2-AM (2.11 × 10−9 mol m−2 s−1) > Co3O4/CeO2-DI (0.840 × 10−9 mol m−2 s−1). This indicates that the modified-synthesis Co3O4/CeO2 catalysts exhibited higher intrinsic catalytic activity, and the specific surface area was not the only determinant factor for the high catalytic performance of the catalyst. In addition, the apparent activation energy (Ea) obtained from the Arrhenius plot was calculated and shown in Fig. 6b and Table 2. A lower apparent activation energy for propane oxidation was evident over Co3O4/CeO2-CA (98.8 kJ mol−1), Co3O4/CeO2-AM (100.7 kJ mol−1) and Co3O4/CeO2-HR (104.9 kJ mol−1), in comparison to Co3O4/CeO2-DI, which exhibited an activation energy of 121.1 kJ mol−1. This indicates that modified-synthesis Co3O4/CeO2 catalysts, particularly Co3O4/CeO2-CA, are more inclined to activate propane. Besides, the catalytic performance of the Co3O4/CeO2-CA catalyst was also evaluated under different space velocities and is shown in Fig. 6c. It was observed that an increase in GHSV led to a higher T90. Remarkably, even at the GHSV up to 120000 mL g−1h−1, the T90 value for propane oxidation over the Co3O4/CeO2-CA catalyst could still remain at 313 °C. This observation highlights the Co3O4/CeO2-CA catalyst’s exceptional performance at elevated GHSV. Apart from the 15 wt% Co3O4/CeO2-CA catalyst, the catalytic activities of Co3O4/CeO2 catalyst with varying Co3O4 loading for propane oxidation were evaluated and shown in Fig. 6d. The activity test results indicate that the Co3O4/CeO2-CA catalyst exhibited better oxidation activity with the increase of Co3O4 loading, except for 20 wt% Co3O4/CeO2-CA catalyst. Besides, the specific Co3O4 mass reaction rate and the catalytic activity of the Co3O4/CeO2-CA catalyst with various Co3O4 loading showed a negative trend (shown in Fig. S4). This underscores that factors beyond Co3O4 loading amounts, such as dispersion, synergic interaction, Co3+ content, and surface oxygen species, paly a significant role in influencing the catalytic activity of supported metal oxide catalysts. In order to delve into the structure–activity relationship of the catalysts, the turnover frequencies (TOFs) of the synthesized Co3O4/CeO2 catalysts were calculated, and the evolution of several parameters that could affect the catalytic performance is shown in Fig. 6e. The TOFs obey the order of Co3O4/CeO2-CA (0.337 × 10−3 s−1) > Co3O4/CeO2-AM (0.322 × 10−3 s−1) > Co3O4/CeO2-HR (0.273 × 10−3 s−1) > Co3O4/CeO2-DI (0.121 × 10−3 s−1). These results consistently demonstrated that the active sites in the modified-synthesis Co3O4/CeO2 catalysts, especially Co3O4/CeO2-CA, showed higher catalytic activity, which dramatically improved the intrinsic catalytic activity for propane oxidation. Besides, the physicochemical properties of the Co3O4/CeO2 catalysts conducive to catalytic activity maintain a good linear relationship. This demonstrates that the highly dispersion of Co3O4 induced by the introduction of CA and AM, along with the reconstruction of CeO2 surface through H2 pretreatment, facilitated the interfacial interaction and electron transfer between Co3O4 and CeO2 (Co2+ + CeO2 → Co3++ 1/2 Ce2O3 + Ov), which further generated more Co3+ and active oxygen species, and thus improved the catalyst activity. Furthermore, in comparison to the catalysts reported (shown in Table 3 ), the Co3O4/CeO2-CA catalyst exhibited superior catalytic performance in propane oxidation, providing a great potential for practical applications in alkanes VOCs removal. The catalytic stability and water resistance of the catalyst are crucial parameters for practical application, so the long-term stability of the Co3O4/CeO2-CA catalyst in propane oxidation under high temperature and moisture was tested. As shown in Fig. 7 a, the Co3O4/CeO2-CA catalyst consistently maintained 90 % propane conversion at 300 °C during the 50-hour test. Notably, no significant degradation in crystal phase was observed (Fig. S5), demonstrating excellent stability during the long-term process. Upon introducing 2.5 vol% H2O into the feed gas, a noticeable reduction in propane conversion over Co3O4/CeO2-CA was observed. However, this decrease could be restored to the initial conversion rate upon discontinuing the water vapor supply, which was due to the facile desorption of H2O molecule from the catalyst’s surface at high temperature. This suggests that the deactivation of the Co3O4/CeO2-CA caused by water vapor is reversible. Cyclic tests were conducted under the same condition as the activity test to evaluate the stability of the Co3O4/CeO2-CA catalyst. As illustrated in Fig. 7b, the catalyst retained comparable activity even after four consecutive heating–cooling cycles, indicating the favorable reusability of the catalyst. All these results indicate that Co3O4/CeO2-CA catalyst possesses good stability and reusability, providing a potential application for practical VOCs removal. 3.4 C3H8-TPD/TPSR analysis and DFT calculation In order to explore the adsorption and activation capabilities of the catalyst on reactant molecules, C3H8-TPD and C3H8-TPSR experiments were carried out. As shown in Fig. 8 a, distinct CO2 peaks between 150 and 320 °C were observed for all Co3O4/CeO2 samples, indicating that reactive oxygen species, mainly surface lattice oxygen species, participate in the oxidation reaction of strongly adsorbed propane. Besides, the CO2 peaks of Co3O4/CeO2-CA, Co3O4/CeO2-AM and Co3O4/CeO2-HR are obviously stronger than that of Co3O4/CeO2-DI, suggesting that the modified-synthesis Co3O4/CeO2 samples enhance the propane activation ability. Fig. 8b displays the C3H8-TPSR profiles of the synthesized Co3O4/CeO2 samples. Notably, upon the introduction of gaseous oxygen, the onset temperature for CO2 generation in the modified-synthesis Co3O4/CeO2 samples was lower than that of Co3O4/CeO2-DI, mainly due to more active chemisorbed oxygen (O2 − and O−) on the modified-synthesis Co3O4/CeO2 samples. Meanwhile, the interface interaction enriched the modified-synthesis Co3O4/CeO2 samples with an increased presence of active oxygen species, enabling propane oxidation at 220–225 °C, which was achieved on Co3O4/CeO2-DI at a higher temperature of 250 °C. It is worth noting that although the CO2 peak intensity (β) of Co3O4/CeO2-DI was higher than that of Co3O4/CeO2-CA and Co3O4/CeO2-HR, the CO2 peak (α) intensity of Co3O4/CeO2-DI was much lower than that of the modified-synthesis Co3O4/CeO2 samples. This indicates that the modified-synthesis Co3O4/CeO2 samples exhibit superior propane oxidation ability compared to Co3O4/CeO2-DI. In summary, the modified-synthesis approach increased the synergistic interaction between Co3O4 and CeO2, making the surface lattice oxygen species of the catalysts more active, thus enhancing the propane oxidation ability. DFT calculation was carried out to elucidate the adsorption configurations of propane and oxygen on the Co3O4/CeO2 catalyst. As establish in previous research, Co3O4 serves as the pivotal active component within the Co3O4/CeO2 catalyst for propane oxidation, and the interfacial interaction between Co3O4 and CeO2 was manifested by the Ce-O-Co and oxygen vacancy (Ov) formation [7,53]. To embody the Co3O4-CeO2 interfacial interaction, the interfacial structure of the catalyst was simplified and idealized, and four potential interface models were constructed (shown in Fig. 8c): the pristine Co3O4 surface (Co3O4), CeO2 influence on Co3O4 surface (Co3O4-CeO2), Co3O4 surface with one Ce atom doping (Co3O4-Ce), Co3O4 surface with two Ce atoms doping (Co3O4-2Ce). Besides, the oxygen vacancy formation energy of the corresponding models was calculated and shown in Fig. S6. It was found that the formation energy of oxygen vacancy reduced from 3.80 eV (Co3O4) to 3.56 eV (Co3O4-Ce) and 3.48 eV (Co3O4-2Ce), indicating that Ce doping promoted the formation of oxygen vacancy on the Co3O4 surface. Therefore, the Co3O4-2Ce-Ov was also made as an interface model to reflect the potential interface where Ce doping prone to generate oxygen vacancy. Full structural details are provided in Supporting Information, Figure S7 and Table S1-S5. For the adsorption on the Co3O4/CeO2 interface, Figs. S8, S9 and 8d show the optimized adsorption configurations and the corresponding adsorption energies of O2 and C3H8 on the Co3O4, Co3O4-CeO2, Co3O4-Ce, Co3O4-2Ce and Co3O4-2Ce-Ov surface, respectively. It is readily apparent that the Co3O4-CeO2 (−1.77 eV) and Co3O4-Ce (−1.86 eV) surface exhibit significantly greater adsorption energy for O2 than the intrinsic Co3O4 (110) surface (−1.65 eV). Specifically, the stronger adsorption took place at the Co3O4-2Ce and Co3O4-2Ce-Ov surface, giving an adsorption energy of −2.23 eV and −2.71 eV. This suggests that the multi-interface between Co3O4 and CeO2 enhances the adsorption O2 molecule. Furthermore, these findings offer a comprehensive explanation for our observations in Fig. 4, where the dissociative adsorption of O2 readily takes place in the modified-synthesis Co3O4/CeO2 samples. In comparison with O2, the adsorption behavior of C3H8 on various surfaces presents a basically distinct tendency. The binding strength of C3H8 on the intrinsic Co3O4 (110) surface (−0.70) is slightly stronger than on the Co3O4-CeO2 (−0.42 eV) and Co3O4-Ce (−0.22 eV) surfaces, which may result from the coverage effect of CeO2 and stabilization effect of Ce atom. Simultaneously, C3H8 binds to the Co3O4-2Ce and Co3O4-2Ce-Ov surface relatively stronger than the intrinsic Co3O4 (110) surface (−1.23 eV, −1.44 eV VS −0.70 eV). These findings show a preferential adsorption of C3H8 molecules on the Co3O4 surface with 2Ce atoms doping and the corresponding oxygen vacancy surface, which indicates that the stronger interaction between Co3O4 and CeO2 promotes the adsorption of C3H8 on the surface. These calculation results explain well our observation that the modified-synthesis Co3O4/CeO2 samples enhance the propane activation ability, which may stem from the increased prevalence of Ce-doped Co3O4 surface in the modified-synthesis Co3O4/CeO2 samples. Fig. 8e summarizes the calculated adsorption energies of O2 and C3H8 on different surfaces. Notably, on the extensively concerned Co3O4-2Ce and Co3O4-2Ce-Ov surface, both the C3H8 and O2 adsorption are stronger than that on the intrinsic Co3O4 (110) surface. This demonstrates that the strong interaction between Co3O4 and CeO2 (especially the incorporation of Ce into Co3O4 lattice) promotes oxygen vacancy generation and the adsorption of C3H8 and O2 on the surface, thus enhancing the catalytic performance of the modified-synthesis Co3O4/CeO2 samples for propane oxidation. 3.5 In-situ DRIFTS analysis To elucidate the intermediates and reaction mechanism involved in propane oxidation, the adsorption and oxidation process of propane on the synthesized Co3O4/CeO2 catalysts under Ar and O2/Ar atmospheres were investigated by the in-situ DRIFTS technique. Fig. 9 a and 9b show the in-situ DRIFT spectra of propane adsorption over the Co3O4/CeO2-DI, Co3O4/CeO2-HR, Co3O4/CeO2-CA and Co3O4/CeO2-AM samples at 50 °C. The observed band at ∼ 2967 and ∼ 2981 cm−1 were attributed to the C–H vibrations of gaseous C3H8, whereas the bands ranging from 2902 to 2971 cm−1 were associated with the C–H vibrations of CH, CH2, or CH3 species [54]. This observation suggests that the adsorption of propane occurred, followed by partially oxidative cracking on the catalyst surface. Moreover, multiple bands were evident in the range of 1200–1700 cm−1, which were attributed to specific vibrational modes, including the asymmetric vibrations of COO− species (∼1546 and 1503 cm−1), asymmetric vibrations of –CH3 species (∼1430 cm−1), symmetric vibration of –CH3 species (∼1348 cm−1), and bidentate carbonate species (∼1318 cm−1) [55]. Besides, the bands centered at ∼ 3464/1628 cm−1 attributed to the v(O–H) of isolated/polymerized –OH group or adsorbed water intensified with prolonged exposure time. The increased formation of the intermediates suggests the activation of propane through interactions with the abundant surface chemisorbed oxygen species on the Co3O4/CeO2 surface, even in an inert condition. Notably, the intensity of bands at ∼ 1546 and ∼ 1430 cm−1 over the modified-synthesis Co3O4/CeO2 catalysts, corresponding to the acetate species, was much higher than that of Co3O4/CeO2-DI catalyst. This phenomenon shows that the augmented production of acetate species likely emanates from the propane activation, facilitated by the presence of active oxygen species intrinsic to the modified-synthesis Co3O4/CeO2 catalysts. Subsequently, 5 vol% O2/Ar was introduced into the reactant gas, and the in-situ DRIFTS spectra were measured for all Co3O4/CeO2 catalysts at the temperature range of 50–350 °C. For Co3O4/CeO2-DI catalyst (shown in Fig. 9c), the bands at 2900–2981 cm−1 attributed to the v(C–H) exhibited a gradual attenuation with increasing temperature. Simultaneously, the majority of the characteristic bands at 1200–1700 cm−1 displayed an initial increase in intensity followed by attenuation as the temperature rose. This suggests that gaseous oxygen supplements the active oxygen species that were consumed on the catalyst surface, leading to a sustained oxidation process with propane. As the temperature ramped to 150 °C, distinctive new bands attributed to the vibration of C = O bonds in acetone (∼1680 cm−1) emerged on the catalyst surface as a result of the ongoing oxidation by active oxygen species. These bands exhibited an initial augmentation followed by subsequent disappearance over the course of the reaction [56]. Upon further elevation of the temperature to 300 and 350 °C, the bands of the previously mentioned intermediates markedly diminished, leaving only a half of bands attributed to carbonates identifiable at ∼ 1546, ∼1507 ∼ 1462 and ∼ 1307 cm−1. Furthermore, the intensity of bands at ∼ 2306 and ∼ 2379 cm−1, corresponding to carbon dioxide generation, displayed a gradually emergence and amplification as the temperature increased from 50 to 350 °C [50,52]. This observation substantiates the involvement of a sequence of intermediates (carboxylate/carbonate species) in propane oxidation, which could subsequently undergo conversion into the ultimate products of CO2 and H2O. The DRIFT spectra of propane oxidation over Co3O4/CeO2-HR, Co3O4/CeO2-CA, and Co3O4/CeO2-AM catalysts are depicted in Fig. 9d-f. Generally, the evolution of intermediates on the Co3O4/CeO2 catalysts exhibit a fundamental similarity with nuanced distinctions, where new bands at ∼ 1740 cm−1 attributed to vas (C = O) stretching vibrations of aliphatic ester group were detected on Co3O4/CeO2-CA and Co3O4/CeO2-AM surface at 150 and 200 °C. This could potentially be attributed to the presence of more active oxygen species in Co3O4/CeO2-CA and Co3O4/CeO2-AM, facilitating the deep oxidation of certain intermediates. Moreover, in contrast to the Co3O4/CeO2-DI catalyst, no additional peaks at 1600–1800 cm−1 were identified for Co3O4/CeO2-HR during the propane oxidation process. Correlating this with the C3H8-TPSR results, it can be deduced that more active oxygen species on Co3O4/CeO2-HR surface promotes the subsequent oxidation of acetone and aliphatic ester intermediates into carboxylates and carbonates species. Building upon the aforementioned experimental and theoretical results, the proposed reaction pathway for propane oxidation over Co3O4/CeO2 catalysts is shown in Fig. 9g. Initially, the adsorbed propane molecules on the Co3O4/CeO2 surface are activated and dissociate into CHn fragments. Subsequently, these CHn fragments engage in reactions with the surface reactive oxygen species, resulting in the formation of intermediates (i.e. carboxylate/carbonate species). Furthermore, with an increase in temperature, additional intermediates like acetone and aliphatic ester groups are generated, which then undergo further oxidization to carboxylate or carbonate species. Simultaneously, gaseous oxygen is adsorbed and activated near the oxygen vacancies to replenish the active oxygen species. Ultimately, the intermediates are consumed and deeply oxidized into the final products of CO2 and H2O. Although the reaction pathway for propane oxidation on the four Co3O4/CeO2 catalysts exhibits fundamental similarity, the variations in adsorption and activation capabilities for propane and O2, along with the differing decomposition capacities of the intermediates, contribute to the disparities observed in their catalytic performance. These distinctions are likely closely linked to the surface properties of the catalysts, such as active oxygen species, redox properties and oxygen vacancies, which are due to the synergistic interaction between Co3O4 and CeO2 originating from the divergent synthesis procedures. 4 Conclusions This study involved the construction of strong interfacial interaction and electron transfer in Co3O4/CeO2 catalysts via the modified wetness impregnation procedures, wherein ammonium hydroxide, citric acid and H2-pretreatment were severally introduced in the synthesis procedure. These modified-synthesis procedures led to the reduction of Co3O4 crystallite size, an enhancement in Co3O4 dispersion and the reconstruction of the CeO2 surface, thus enhancing the interfacial interaction and electron transfer in Co3O4/CeO2. The Co3O4/CeO2-CA catalyst exhibited superior catalytic activity (T90 = 296 °C, TOF = 0.337 × 10−3 s−1) and stability for propane oxidation, as compared to typical wetness impregnation Co3O4/CeO2-DI (T90 = 314 °C, TOF = 0.121 × 10−3 s−1). C3H8-TPD/TPSR and DFT calculations demonstrate that the interfacial interaction between Co3O4 and CeO2 promotes the adsorption and activation of C3H8 and O2 on the catalyst surface. Furthermore, in situ DRIFTS analysis further reveals that abundant reactive oxygen species on the modified-synthesis Co3O4/CeO2 surface accelerates the intermediates (carbonate/carboxyl species) transformation into CO2. This study highlights experimental insights into the interfacial active sites of Co3O4/CeO2 in propane oxidation, contributing to an in-depth understanding of C–H bond activation in light hydrocarbons and the construction of supported transition metal oxide catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Tuning the nanoparticle-support interaction can optimize the catalytic performance of supported metal oxide catalysts for VOCs removal. Herein, a series of Co3O4/CeO2 catalysts with different strengths of interfacial interaction and electron transfer were successfully constructed via various modified wetness impregnation procedures. With the introduction of ammonium hydroxide, citric acid or H2 pretreatment, a stronger interfacial interaction and electron transfer were achieved due to the highly Co3O4 dispersion and CeO2 surface reconstruction. The modified-synthesis Co3O4/CeO2 catalysts, particularly Co3O4/CeO2-CA (citric acid), demonstrated superior catalytic activity (T90 = 296 °C, TOF = 0.337 × 10−3 s−1) and stability for propane oxidation as compared to typical wetness impregnation Co3O4/CeO2-DI (T90 = 314 °C, TOF = 0.121 × 10−3 s−1). Through systematic characterizations and DFT calculation, the strong interfacial interaction and abundant reactive oxygen species facilitate the adsorption and activation of C3H8 and O2 on the catalyst surface, which further promote the intermediates (carbonate/carboxyl species) transformation. These findings highlight interfacial mechanism to catalytic performance optimization of supported metal oxides.
coredata.dc:title: Boosting catalytic oxidation of propane over CeO2-supported Co3O4 catalyst with strong interfacial interaction and electron transfer
